This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question.

(12 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

Students are performing various electrostatic experiments to investigate charge distribution. The students have a charged plastic disk with an insulating handle and two uncharged metal plates.

(a) The students begin by bringing the charged plastic disk near the uncharged metal plates, as shown above. On the figure, draw the charge distribution on both of the metal plates.

(b) In another experiment, the students want to determine the charge on the plates of a capacitor by measuring the plate separation and potential difference between the plates. They have a capacitor with plates of area <math alttext="0.0025 square meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0025</mn><msup><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is also the area of the plastic disk. The capacitor plate separation <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> can be varied. To charge the capacitor, the students bring the plastic disk very near but not touching one of the capacitor plates, as shown below, and connect the plates with a wire. Then they remove the wire before removing the plastic disk. The students vary the separation <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and record the potential difference <math alttext="delta V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the plates. The table below contains the data the students collect.

Plate Separation <math alttext="d, in meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.002" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.002</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.004" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.004</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.006" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.006</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.008" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.008</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.010" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.010</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.012" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.012</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

Potential Difference <math alttext="delta V, in volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>V</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="33" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>33</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="57" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>57</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="75" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>75</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="88" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>88</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="115" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>115</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

i. What quantities should the students plot to create a linear graph that will allow them to calculate the magnitude of the charge on one of the capacitor plates?

ii. On the grid below, create a linear graph using the values for the quantities indicated in part (b)(i). Use the additional rows in the table to record any quantities you indicated that must be calculated from the students’ data. Be sure to do the following.

Label the axes with the quantities that are plotted, including units.

Scale the axes.

Plot the data and draw a line that best represents the data.
iii. Using the graph, calculate the charge on one of the capacitor plates.

(c) In a third experiment, students have various charged plastic disks that are on insulating handles. The amount of charge on each disk is different, but in each case it is distributed uniformly. The students also have an aluminum can with a strip of aluminum foil taped to it, so that most of the foil hangs free, as shown above. The apparatus is placed on an insulating surface. Describe a procedure that would allow the students to use the apparatus to compare the amount of charge on each of the disks without allowing anything to touch the disks.
